Subject: Re: [neat] New Paper on the Problem with Objectives in Evolution

Ken,

First off, I'll say that what I take as the central point, that EAs c=
an miss
critical intermediate objectives because they are awkwardly placed =
on the
fitness landscape, is a good one.  However, I have some concerns abo=
ut the
experimental design in this paper:

(1) You appear to be manipulatin=
g two variables at once.  (a) whether the EA
has an objective and (b) wheth=
er there is a human in the loop.  Surely you
have to pick only one at a tim=
e and control for everything else, right?

(2) Furthermore, if it's IGA v. =
GA and 'interestingness' is the evaluation
criteria, that ain't a fair figh=
t.  Why should I believe there is more to it
than that?

(3) How do we know=
 that intermediate objectives are in any way significant
to discovering int=
eresting pictures in Picbreeder?  I have a sneaking
suspicion that totally =
random search, followed by focused objective based
search when something 'p=
ops' might be just as effective, and that the
'intermediate objectives', wh=
ile certainly necessary to find a
*particular*image, are not very helpful i=
n general to finding
interesting images.  If
so, this is no chink in the ar=
mor of objective based search.  I suppose
without intermediate objectives t=
here can be no exaptation, but does that
matter?  What percentage of evolve=
d features in biological organisms have
any exaptation at all in their hist=
ory?

(4) Finally - and this is the big one - one of the deadly sins of Sci=
ence is
claiming a result as the objective a posteriori, a point which elud=
es even
some very famous scientists.  It's what allows publications like
th=
is<http://www.wired.com/wiredscience/2010/11/feeling-the-future-is-precogni=
tion-possible/>,
which
'prove' psychic phenomena by mining data for 'statis=
tically significant'
results.  The problem is, a result isn't significant u=
nless you were
specifically attempting to confirm it when the experiment wa=
s designed (i.e.
always follow up exploratory experiment with a confirmator=
y experiment!).  I
heartily endorse exploring for/marvelling at results you=
 weren't initially
looking for, but one should never use such results as th=
e basis for any sort
of comparison.  In the case of the eye experiment, who=
 cares if the GA
couldn't evolve the eye?  The IGA can't either, and the fa=
ct that it already
did is immaterial!  I could be persuaded that the IGA is=
 better at evolving
interesting images, but I do not believe it's any bette=
r at evolving the
'eye' (or 'dolphin', or 'apple').  In fact, I would bet t=
hat's it's
*worse*at evolving those specific images, intermediate objective=
s
notwithstanding.

Anyway, though I have a lot of doubts about this partic=
ular paper, I really
appreciate these sorts of research directions.  Keep u=
p the good work!

Daniel

On Fri, Apr 1, 2011 at 7:09 PM, Ken <kstanley@cs.=
utexas.edu> wrote:

>
>
> Brian Woolley and I are pleased to announce our n=
ew paper to appear at
> GECCO, "On the Deleterious Effects of A Priori Obje=
ctives on Evolution and
> Representation." You can get it here:
>
> http://=
eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/woolley_gecco11.pdf
>
> Abstract:
> http://eplex.cs=
.ucf.edu/publications/2011/woolley.gecco11.html
>
> As some of you have bee=
n following through our articles on novelty search
> and my keynote talk on=
 "Searching Without Objectives," our research group
> has been questioning =
the role of objectives in evolution and machine
> learning. However, much o=
f this focus has been on exploring alternative
> paradigms such as novelty =
search. In contrast, this new paper aims to expose
> directly some of the m=
ost serious problems with objective-based search
> itself, both practically=
 and philosophically.
>
> The message is not only that objectives may not b=
e the best way to drive
> evolution. Perhaps deeper than that, the results =
suggest that the usual way
> we evaluate our algorithms, i.e. by giving the=
m a task and seeing how
> reliably they can solve it, may be flawed in the =
sense that it may not
> actually be accurately measuring the real potential=
 of such algorithms. We
> probably should rethink whether demanding the sam=
e result over and over
> again with 100% reliability is really a good way t=
o ascertain the potential
> an evolutionary algorithm. The paper gives the =
full story.
>
> ken
>
>  
>

--90e6ba1efc189219da049fe5fa26

Ken,=A0<div><br></div><div>First off, I'll say that what I take as the =
central point,=A0that EAs can miss critical intermediate objectives because=
 they are awkwardly placed on the fitness landscape, is a good one. =A0Howe=
ver, I have some concerns about the experimental design in this paper:</div=
>

<div><br></div><div>(1) You appear to be manipulating two variables at o=
nce. =A0(a) whether the EA has an objective and (b) whether there is a huma=
n in the loop. =A0Surely you have to pick only one at a time and control fo=
r everything else, right? =A0</div>

<div><br></div><div>(2) Furthermore, i=
f it's IGA v. GA and 'interestingness' is the evaluation criter=
ia, that ain't a fair fight. =A0Why should I believe there is more to i=
t than that?</div><div><br></div><div>

(3)=A0How do we know that intermedi=
ate objectives are in any way significant to discovering interesting pictur=
es in Picbreeder? =A0I have a sneaking suspicion that totally random search=
, followed by focused objective based search when something 'pops' =
might be just as effective, and that the 'intermediate objectives',=
 while certainly necessary to find a <i>particular</i> image, are not very =
helpful in general to finding interesting images. =A0If so, this is no chin=
k in the armor of objective based search. =A0I suppose without intermediate=
 objectives there can be no exaptation, but does that matter? =A0What perce=
ntage of evolved features in biological organisms have any exaptation at al=
l in their history?</div>

<div><br></div><div>(4) Finally - and this is th=
e big one - one of the deadly sins of Science is claiming a result as the o=
bjective a posteriori, a point which eludes even some very famous scientist=
s. =A0It's what allows publications like <a href=3D"http://www.wired.co=
m/wiredscience/2010/11/feeling-the-future-is-precognition-possible/">this</=
a>,=A0which 'prove' psychic phenomena by mining data for 'stati=
stically significant' results. =A0The problem is, a result isn't si=
gnificant unless you were specifically attempting to confirm it when the ex=
periment was designed (i.e. always follow up exploratory experiment with a =
confirmatory experiment!). =A0I heartily endorse exploring for/marvelling a=
t results you weren't initially looking for, but one should never use s=
uch results as the basis for any sort of comparison. =A0In the case of the =
eye experiment, who cares if the GA couldn't evolve the eye? =A0The IGA=
 can't either, and the fact that it already did is immaterial! =A0I cou=
ld be persuaded that the IGA is better at evolving interesting images, but =
I do not believe it's any better at evolving the 'eye' (or &#39=
;dolphin', or 'apple'). =A0In fact, I would bet that's it&#=
39;s <i>worse</i> at evolving those specific images, intermediate objective=
s notwithstanding.</div>

<div><br></div><div>Anyway, though I have a lot o=
f doubts about this particular paper, I really appreciate these sorts of re=
search directions. =A0Keep up the good work!</div><div><br></div><div>Danie=
l</div><div><br><div class=3D"gmail_quote">

On Fri, Apr 1, 2011 at 7:09 PM=
, Ken <span dir=3D"ltr"><<a href=3D"mailto:kstanley@...">kstan=
ley@...</a>></span> wrote:<br><blockquote class=3D"gmail_quote=

iv>
  <div>


    <div>
      
      
      <p>Brian Woolley and I are plea=
sed to announce our new paper to appear at GECCO, "On the Deleterious =
Effects of A Priori Objectives on Evolution and Representation."  You =
can get it here:<br>
<br>
<a href=3D"http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/woolley=
_gecco11.pdf" target=3D"_blank">http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/woolley_gecc=
o11.pdf</a><br>
<br>
Abstract: <br>
<a href=3D"http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publ=
ications/2011/woolley.gecco11.html" target=3D"_blank">http://eplex.cs.ucf.e=
du/publications/2011/woolley.gecco11.html</a><br>
<br>
As some of you have =
been following through our articles on novelty search and my keynote talk o=
n "Searching Without Objectives," our research group has been que=
stioning the role of objectives in evolution and machine learning.  However=
, much of this focus has been on exploring alternative paradigms such as no=
velty search.  In contrast, this new paper aims to expose directly some of =
the most serious problems with objective-based search itself, both practica=
lly and philosophically.<br>


<br>
The message is not only that objectives=
 may not be the best way to drive evolution.  Perhaps deeper than that, the=
 results suggest that the usual way we evaluate our algorithms, i.e. by giv=
ing them a task and seeing how reliably they can solve it, may be flawed in=
 the sense that it may not actually be accurately measuring the real potent=
ial of such algorithms.  We probably should rethink whether demanding the s=
ame result over and over again with 100% reliability is really a good way t=
o ascertain the potential an evolutionary algorithm.  The paper gives the f=
ull story.<br>


<br>
ken<br>
<br>
</p>

    </div>

yle=3D"color:#fff;min-height:0"></div>
